abstract.t: This draft provides the specification for the HAT(Harry's Allocation Table) filesystem. It is intended to provide a clear reference for anyone wishing to implement this filesystem.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Currently there is no standard filesystem designed for use in a system built around the DCPU-16 architecture. This RFC provides a filesystem designed specifically for use on DCPU-16 systems.
HAT is designed to be simple and easy to implement while still providing all the features required of a filesystem.

section.title: Data Structures
section.t: This section defines the data structures that comprise the HAT filesystem.
All sizes are given in words, which are considered to be 16 bits long.

section.title: Header
section.t: This structure contains the header information for HAT.
The total size of the header is 16 words.

section.title: version
section.t: The version field is a magic number that identifies both that the filesystem in use is HAT and the version of HAT.
The value of this field must be 0x4001. This magic number identifies the filesystem as version one of HAT.

section.title: flags
section.t: Bit 0 is the least significant bit, Bit 15 is the most significant bit.

section.title: is_mounted
section.t: If this filesystem is currently mounted then this field must be set to 1, otherwise it must be set to 0.

section.title: num_inodes
section.t: This field contains the total number of INodes in the filesystem.

section.title: num_blocks
section.t: This field contains the total number of Blocks in the filesystem.

section.title: inode_start
section.t: This field contains the address of the first inode on disk.

section.title: inode_start
section.t: This field contains the address of the first block on disk.

section.title: block_size
section.t: This field contains the size of each block in the filesystem.
This must be a power of 2, such as 128, 256 or 512.

section.title: INode
section.t: The INode structure is used to store metadata about files. It is used to find the contents of the file on disk and the relationship of that file to the directory structure.
The INode structure is 32 words.

section.title: flags
section.t: Bit 0 is the least significant bit, Bit 15 is the most significant bit.

section.title: in_use
section.t: If the INode represents a file or directory in the filesystem that is valid and has not been deleted then this field must be set to 1. If the INode is not in use then this field must be set to 0.

section.title: is_directory
section.t: If the INode represents a file then this flag must be set to 0. If the INode represents a directory then this flag must be set to 1.

section.title: is_executable
section.t: If the INode represents a binary file that can be executed then this flag should be set to 1, otherwise it should be set to 0.

section.title: is_writable
section.t: If this flag is set then it must not be possible to write to or modify the file in any way other than changing this flag.

section.title: parent_inode
section.t: This field contains the index of the INode's parent. Every INode has a parent except for the root INode whose parent is undefined and ignored.

section.title: content_size
section.t: This field behaves differently depending on whether the INode represents a file or a directory. If the INode represents a file then this field is set to the size of the file's contents in words. If the INode represents a directory then this field is set to the number of children the INode has.

section.title: block_index
section.t: This field contains the index of the first data block.

section.title: file_name
section.t: This field contains a null terminated string, which is the file name of the INode.
Only alphanumeric characters, periods(.) and underscores(_) are allowed in the filename.

section.title: Block
section.t: The block structure is used to store raw data for the INodes. When an INode represents a file, blocks are used to store the file data. When an INode represents a directory, blocks are used to store the children of the INode.

section.title: next_block_index
section.t: This field contains the index of the block that follows this one. When there is no such block this field's value is undefined as the number of blocks known is determined by the content_size field of the INode structure.

section.title: block_data
section.t: This field is used differently depending on whether the INode that uses this block is representing a file or a directory.
If the INode is a file then this field contains the raw file data.
If the INode is a directory then this field contains a list of the INode indexes of the children of the INode.
The size of this field is determined by the block_size field in the header of the filesystem.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: As there is no way to prevent programs from accessing the disk directly and reading/writing data HAT makes no attempt at providing any data security.
